title: demor
text: getting data RosBris function get_rosbris() can download data mortality/fertility 1/5-year age groups 1989 last available year (2023 2022). Worth noting: downloading preparing final file can get time. chunk mortality data 5-age groups population “long” format loading. function description use ?get_rosbris Lets see data Russia 2010 males total population (urban rural)
code: library(demor)  dbm <- get_rosbris(   #mortality data   type = "m",   #what age group download   age =  5,   #to get "long" data   initial = F,   #last available year (the name of the downloading file contains years, so for the downloading the last year is required)   lastyear = 2022 ) dbm[dbm$year==2010 & dbm$code==1100 & dbm$sex=="m" & dbm$territory=="t",] #>       year code territory sex age       mx       N        Dx #> 20445 2010 1100         t   m   0 0.008823  869388   7670.61 #> 20446 2010 1100         t   m   1 0.000604 3222450   1946.36 #> 20447 2010 1100         t   m   5 0.000355 3613276   1282.71 #> 20448 2010 1100         t   m  10 0.000387 3398894   1315.37 #> 20449 2010 1100         t   m  15 0.001186 4353344   5163.07 #> 20450 2010 1100         t   m  20 0.002546 6193325  15768.21 #> 20451 2010 1100         t   m  25 0.004491 6002262  26956.16 #> 20452 2010 1100         t   m  30 0.006808 5395865  36735.05 #> 20453 2010 1100         t   m  35 0.007934 4973298  39458.15 #> 20454 2010 1100         t   m  40 0.009782 4464789  43674.57 #> 20455 2010 1100         t   m  45 0.013354 5140274  68643.22 #> 20456 2010 1100         t   m  50 0.018567 5207919  96695.43 #> 20457 2010 1100         t   m  55 0.026250 4333619 113757.50 #> 20458 2010 1100         t   m  60 0.037143 3117320 115786.62 #> 20459 2010 1100         t   m  65 0.049925 1573662  78565.08 #> 20460 2010 1100         t   m  70 0.068599 2149929 147482.98 #> 20461 2010 1100         t   m  75 0.097635 1077916 105242.33 #> 20462 2010 1100         t   m  80 0.138043  714191  98589.07 #> 20463 2010 1100         t   m  85 0.198593  231350  45944.49 #>                       name #> 20445 Российская Федерация #> 20446 Российская Федерация #> 20447 Российская Федерация #> 20448 Российская Федерация #> 20449 Российская Федерация #> 20450 Российская Федерация #> 20451 Российская Федерация #> 20452 Российская Федерация #> 20453 Российская Федерация #> 20454 Российская Федерация #> 20455 Российская Федерация #> 20456 Российская Федерация #> 20457 Российская Федерация #> 20458 Российская Федерация #> 20459 Российская Федерация #> 20460 Российская Федерация #> 20461 Российская Федерация #> 20462 Российская Федерация #> 20463 Российская Федерация

title: demor
text: Now one can create life table based gotten data 2010-Russia using LT(). Note, \(a_x\) age 0 modeled Andreev & Kingkade (2015). Note, life table one can compute functions (just \(e_x\) \(l_x\)): 1. \(CDR = \frac{1}{e_0}\) Death rate age \(x: 1/e_x\). 2. Probability surviving age \(x\) age \(y\): \(p=l_y/l_x\). 3. Probability newborn die ages \(x\) \(x+n\): \(d_x^n/l_0\). 4. Probability newborn die ages \(x\) \(y\): \((l_x-l_y)/l_0\). 5. Life course ratio age \(x\) \(y\) fraction person-years lived age \(x\) onward: \(T_y/T_x\).

title: demor
text: good alternative human development indicator (HDI) human life indicator (HLI) proposed Ghislandi, Sanderson Scherbov (2019). requires just \(m_x\) (based life table). calculated geometric mean lifespans: \[HLI = \prod_x^\omega{(x+a_x)^{d_x}}\] x age , d functions life table. Lets calculate using example data:
code: hli(   age = rus2010$age,    sex = "m",    mx = rus2010$mx) #> [1] 55.19236

title: demor
text: One popular (relatively young) measure lifespan inequality “years life lost” (YLL) proposed Martinez et al. (2019). authors claim, “YLL valuable measure public health surveillance, particularly quantifying level trends premature mortality, identification leading causes premature deaths monitoring progress YLL key indicator population health” (ibid., 1368). Authors proposed different metrics YLL: 1. Absolute number YLL: \[YLL_{x,t,c}=D_{x,t,c}*SLE_x\] calculated age x, time t cause death c. YLL whole population just sum \(YLL_x\). SLE standard life expectancy invariant time, sex population (’s meaning straightforward: potential maximum life span individual, exposed avoidable health risks severe injuries receives appropriate health services), \(D_x\) number deaths age x. course, one can calculate YLL specific cause c, overall mortality called -causes YLL. 2. YLL proportion: \[YLL^p_{x,t,c}=YLL_{x,t,c}/YLL_{x,t}\] just cause specific YLL divided -causes YLL. 3. YLL rate: \[YLL^r_{x,t,c}=[YLL_{x,t,c}/P_{x,t}] * 100'000\] \(P_{x,t}\) population. 4. Age-standardized YLL rate: \[ASYR_{x,t,c} = \sum_x^\omega{[YLL^r_{x,t,c}*W_x]}\] \(W_x\) standard population weight age x, \(\omega\) oldest, closing age (ex., 85+ 100+). words, ’s just direct standardization \(YLL^r_{x,t,c}\). Let’s calculate -cause YLL, Yll rate ASYR using Rosbris data downloaded. ASYR one needs standard population. Let’s use 2010 population standard (note, case ASYR equals YLL rate use 2010 mortality). Also one can calculate different YLL measures using standards provided demor dataframe.

what: Age decomposition of differences in life expectancies
title: demor
text: Also one can simple decomposition 2 populations. Lets use Russia-2000 base population Russia-2010 compared population let us plot result decomp using R basic plot.  using ggplot2

what: Age and cause decomposition of differences in life expectancies
title: demor
text: Also one can decomposition 2 populations age causes. Lets use example Andreev & Shkolnikov spreadsheet data US England Wales men mortality causes presented. Lets see data mdecomp 2 lists arrays 2 population required. let us plot result mdecomp using ggplot2. requires data transformations
code: data("mdecompex") head(mdecompex) #> # A tibble: 6 × 9 #>     age neoplasms circulatory respiratory  digestive  accident     other     all #>   <dbl>     <dbl>       <dbl>       <dbl>      <dbl>     <dbl>     <dbl>   <dbl> #> 1     0 0.0000349  0.000173    0.000188   0.000151   0.000377  0.00669   7.62e-3 #> 2     1 0.0000309  0.0000155   0.0000220  0.00000930 0.000163  0.000112  3.53e-4 #> 3     5 0.0000313  0.00000560  0.00000687 0.00000324 0.0000792 0.0000409 1.67e-4 #> 4    10 0.0000305  0.0000127   0.00000896 0.00000286 0.000127  0.0000490 2.31e-4 #> 5    15 0.0000424  0.0000322   0.0000141  0.00000401 0.000765  0.0000821 9.40e-4 #> 6    20 0.0000600  0.0000511   0.0000158  0.00000928 0.00114   0.000130  1.41e-3 #> # ℹ 1 more variable: cnt <chr> #US men mx1 <- list(all = mdecompex[mdecompex$cnt=="usa",]$all,              neoplasm = mdecompex[mdecompex$cnt=="usa",]$neoplasms,              circulatory = mdecompex[mdecompex$cnt=="usa",]$circulatory,              respiratory = mdecompex[mdecompex$cnt=="usa",]$respiratory,             digestive = mdecompex[mdecompex$cnt=="usa",]$digestive,             accident = mdecompex[mdecompex$cnt=="usa",]$accident,             other = mdecompex[mdecompex$cnt=="usa",]$other) #England and Wales men mx2 <- list(all = mdecompex[mdecompex$cnt=="eng",]$all,              neoplasm = mdecompex[mdecompex$cnt=="eng",]$neoplasms,              circulatory = mdecompex[mdecompex$cnt=="eng",]$circulatory,              respiratory = mdecompex[mdecompex$cnt=="eng",]$respiratory,             digestive = mdecompex[mdecompex$cnt=="eng",]$digestive,             accident = mdecompex[mdecompex$cnt=="eng",]$accident,             other = mdecompex[mdecompex$cnt=="eng",]$other)  decm <- mdecomp(mx1 = mx1,                mx2 = mx2,                sex = "m",                age = unique(mdecompex$age)               ) head(decm) #>   age ex12      neoplasm  circulatory   respiratory     digestive   accident #> 1   0 0.12  0.0008745885 6.544742e-03  0.0038965543  6.616401e-03 0.02107294 #> 2   1 0.03 -0.0025030458 5.483996e-04  0.0020247182  6.245908e-04 0.03637029 #> 3   5 0.02 -0.0016468368 8.262058e-05 -0.0001300012  9.929857e-05 0.02178479 #> 4  10 0.01 -0.0014084238 4.993427e-04 -0.0002451017  8.338450e-05 0.01117647 #> 5  15 0.13 -0.0032690840 2.657675e-03  0.0005053688 -2.052103e-04 0.13796276 #> 6  20 0.17 -0.0009648903 2.773336e-03 -0.0016773417 -8.983808e-04 0.18353643 #>           other #> 1  0.0809947781 #> 2 -0.0070649563 #> 3 -0.0001898743 #> 4 -0.0001056675 #> 5 -0.0076515085 #> 6 -0.0127691565 library(ggplot2)  decm_plot <- decm[,c(1,3)] decm_plot$group = colnames(decm)[3] colnames(decm_plot)[2]<-"ex12" for(i in 4:ncol(decm)){   decm_plot_i <- decm[,c(1,i)]   decm_plot_i$group = colnames(decm)[i]   colnames(decm_plot_i)[2]<-"ex12"   decm_plot <- rbind(decm_plot,decm_plot_i)   rm(decm_plot_i) }  for (i in unique(decm_plot$group)){   decm_plot[decm_plot$group==i,]$group <- paste0(i, " (", round(sum(decm_plot[decm_plot$group==i,]$ex12),2), ")") }  ggplot(data = decm_plot, aes(x = as.factor(age), y = ex12, fill = group))+   geom_bar(stat="identity", colour = "black")+   theme_minimal()+   scale_fill_brewer(palette="Set1")+   labs(x = "Age", y = "Contribution to difference in ex", fill = "Cause (contribution):",         caption  = paste0("Total difference in ex = ", sum(decm[,2]))        )

title: demor
text: Also demor leecart() function provides users basic Lee-Carter model (proposed Lee Carter 1992 now lot extensions) mortality forecasting: One can plot results using ggplot2:
code: leecart_forecast <- leecart(data = dbm[dbm$code==1100 & dbm$territory=="t" & dbm$sex=="m" & dbm$year %in% 2004:2019,c("year", "age", "mx")],                              n = 10,                              sex = "m",                              concise = T                             ) head(leecart_forecast) #>   year age           mx     mx_low95    mx_high95    ex ex_low95 ex_high95 #> 1 2020   0 0.0052050868 0.0049297552 0.0054957958 68.54    67.99     69.08 #> 2 2020   1 0.0003032973 0.0002852915 0.0003224396 67.89    67.36     68.42 #> 3 2020  10 0.0002669130 0.0002568045 0.0002774194 63.97    63.45     64.50 #> 4 2020  15 0.0007304609 0.0006953816 0.0007673099 59.06    58.53     59.58 #> 5 2020  20 0.0013011257 0.0012188971 0.0013889016 54.26    53.75     54.78 #> 6 2020  25 0.0019688556 0.0018300568 0.0021181815 49.60    49.10     50.10 ggplot(data = leecart_forecast[leecart_forecast$age=="0",], aes(year, ex))+   geom_line()+geom_ribbon(aes(ymin = ex_low95, ymax = ex_high95), alpha = 0.3, fill = "red")+   theme_classic()+   scale_x_continuous(breaks = seq(2020, 2030, 2)) ggplot(data = leecart_forecast, aes(as.numeric(age), log10(mx), color = as.factor(year)))+   geom_line()+geom_ribbon(aes(ymin = log10(mx_low95), ymax = log10(mx_high95)), alpha = 0)+   theme_minimal()+   labs(x = "Age", color = "Year:")

title: demor
text: asdt() function calculates associated single decrement life table (ASDT) causes death (cause-deleted life table). words, function one can answer question “life expectancy mortality cause ?” example demor data (easy guess, taken Andreev & Shkolnikov spreadsheet) mortality US men 2002 causes added. Let show \(e_x\) deaths neoplasm () One can plot results using ggplot2:
code: data("asdtex")  asdt_neoplasm <- asdt(age = asdtex$age,                        sex = "m",                       m_all = asdtex$all,                        m_i = asdtex$neoplasms,                        full = F,                        method = "chiang1968") asdt_neoplasm[,c("age", "ex", "ex_without_i")] #>    age    ex ex_without_i #> 1    0 74.65        78.58 #> 2    1 74.22        78.18 #> 3    5 70.32        74.28 #> 4   10 65.38        69.33 #> 5   15 60.45        64.39 #> 6   20 55.72        59.67 #> 7   25 51.10        55.06 #> 8   30 46.43        50.39 #> 9   35 41.75        45.72 #> 10  40 37.16        41.13 #> 11  45 32.70        36.64 #> 12  50 28.39        32.26 #> 13  55 24.25        27.98 #> 14  60 20.32        23.82 #> 15  65 16.69        19.84 #> 16  70 13.40        16.12 #> 17  75 10.51        12.75 #> 18  80  8.07         9.81 #> 19  85  6.15         7.32 library(ggplot2)  ggplot(data = asdt_neoplasm, aes(x = age))+   geom_line(aes(y = ex, color = "ex"), size = 1)+   geom_line(aes(y = ex_without_i, color = "ex without neoplasms"), size = 1)+   theme_minimal() ggplot(data = asdt_neoplasm, aes(x = age))+   geom_line(aes(y = lx, color = "ex"), size = 1)+   geom_line(aes(y = l_not_i, color = "ex without neoplasms"), size = 1)+   geom_hline(yintercept = 0.5, linetype = "dashed")+   theme_classic()

title: demor
text: analysis fertility demor (1…) functions, due author’s preference mortality analysis…

title: demor
text: Lets get basic fertility data (asFR \(f_x\)) RosBris using get_rosbris() example Russia-2010 gotten Now one can compute TFR:
code: dbf <- get_rosbris(   #fertility data   type = "f",   #what age group download   age =  5,   #to get "long" data   initial = F,   #last available year   lastyear = 2022 ) rus2010f <- dbf[dbf$year==2010 & dbf$code==1100 & dbf$territory=="t",] rus2010f #>      year code territory age       fx       N        Bx                 name #> 3153 2010 1100         t  15 0.027015 4214250 113847.96 Российская Федерация #> 3154 2010 1100         t  20 0.087421 6027079 526893.27 Российская Федерация #> 3155 2010 1100         t  25 0.099061 5957982 590203.65 Российская Федерация #> 3156 2010 1100         t  30 0.067240 5515957 370892.95 Российская Федерация #> 3157 2010 1100         t  35 0.029922 5187670 155225.46 Российская Федерация #> 3158 2010 1100         t  40 0.005904 4764028  28126.82 Российская Федерация #> 3159 2010 1100         t  45 0.000257 5738736   1474.86 Российская Федерация #> 3160 2010 1100         t  50 0.000014 6203597     86.85 Российская Федерация tfr(   #asFR   rus2010f$fx,   #age interval   age.int = 5     ) #> [1] 1.58417

title: demor
text: Also demor additional functions. One plot_pyr plots population pyramid using ggplot2 Lets create population pyramid using midyear population Rosbris mortality data. already data dbm.  Also one can redesigned plot using ggplot2 functions:
code: plot_pyr(   popm = dbm[dbm$year==2010 & dbm$code==1100 & dbm$territory=="t" & dbm$sex=="m",]$N,   popf = dbm[dbm$year==2010 & dbm$code==1100 & dbm$territory=="t" & dbm$sex=="f",]$N,    ages = dbm[dbm$year==2010 & dbm$code==1100 & dbm$territory=="t" & dbm$sex=="f",]$age) plot <-    plot_pyr(   popm = dbm[dbm$year==2010 & dbm$code==1100 & dbm$territory=="t" & dbm$sex=="m",]$N,   popf = dbm[dbm$year==2010 & dbm$code==1100 & dbm$territory=="t" & dbm$sex=="f",]$N,    ages = dbm[dbm$year==2010 & dbm$code==1100 & dbm$territory=="t" & dbm$sex=="f",]$age)  plot +    labs(y = "My y", x = "Age")+   theme_minimal()

title: demor
text: Center Demographic Research (2023). Russian Fertility Mortality Database (Rosbris). URL Andreev, E. M., & Kingkade, W. W. (2015). Average age death infancy infant mortality level: Reconsidering Coale-Demeny formulas current levels low mortality. Demographic Research, 33, 363-390. Ghislandi, S., Sanderson, W. C., & Scherbov, S. (2019). simple measure human development: human life indicator. Population development review, 45(1), 219-233. Andreev, E. M., & Shkolnikov, V. M. (2012). Excel spreadsheet decomposition difference two values aggregate demographic measure stepwise replacement running young old ages. MPIDR Technical Report TR-2012-002. URL Lee, R. D., & Carter, L. R. (1992). Modeling forecasting US mortality. Journal American statistical association, 87(419), 659-671. Ghislandi, S., Sanderson, W.C., & Scherbov, S. (2019). Simple Measure Human Development: Human Life Indicator. Population Development Review, 45, 219–233.

code: library(demor)  dbm <- get_rosbris(   #mortality data   type = "m",   #what age group download   age =  5,   #to get "long" data   initial = F,   #last available year (the name of the downloading file contains years, so for the downloading the last year is required)   lastyear = 2022 ) dbm[dbm$year==2010 & dbm$code==1100 & dbm$sex=="m" & dbm$territory=="t",] #>       year code territory sex age       mx       N        Dx #> 20445 2010 1100         t   m   0 0.008823  869388   7670.61 #> 20446 2010 1100         t   m   1 0.000604 3222450   1946.36 #> 20447 2010 1100 title: Basic functions for demographic analysis
text: Now one can create life table based gotten data 2010-Russia using LT(). Note, ax age 0 modeled Andreev & Kingkade (2015). Note, life table one can compute functions (just ex lx): 1. $CDR = \frac{1}{e_0}$ Death rate age x : 1/ex. 2. Probability surviving age x age y: p = ly/lx. 3. Probability newborn die ages x x + n: dxn/l0. 4. Probability newborn die ages x y: (lx−ly)/l0. 5. Life course ratio age x y fraction person-years lived age x onward: Ty/Tx.

title: Basic functions for demographic analysis
text: good alternative human development indicator (HDI) human life indicator (HLI) proposed Ghislandi, Sanderson Scherbov (2019). requires just mx (based life table). calculated geometric mean lifespans: $$HLI = \prod_x^\omega{(x+a_x)^{d_x}}$$ x age , d functions life table. Lets calculate using example data:
code: hli(   age = rus2010$age,    sex = "m",    mx = rus2010$mx) #> [1] 55.19236

title: Basic functions for demographic analysis
text: One popular (relatively young) measure lifespan inequality “years life lost” (YLL) proposed Martinez et al. (2019). authors claim, “YLL valuable measure public health surveillance, particularly quantifying level trends premature mortality, identification leading causes premature deaths monitoring progress YLL key indicator population health” (ibid., 1368). Authors proposed different metrics YLL: 1. Absolute number YLL: YLLx, t, c = Dx, t, c * SLEx calculated age x, time t cause death c. YLL whole population just sum YLLx. SLE standard life expectancy invariant time, sex population (’s meaning straightforward: potential maximum life span individual, exposed avoidable health risks severe injuries receives appropriate health services), Dx number deaths age x. course, one can calculate YLL specific cause c, overall mortality called -causes YLL. 2. YLL proportion: YLLx, t, cp = YLLx, t, c/YLLx, t just cause specific YLL divided -causes YLL. 3. YLL rate: YLLx, t, cr = [YLLx, t, c/Px, t] * 100′000 Px, t population. 4. Age-standardized YLL rate: $$ASYR_{x,t,c} = \sum_x^\omega{[YLL^r_{x,t,c}*W_x]}$$ Wx standard population weight age x, ω oldest, closing age (ex., 85+ 100+). words, ’s just direct standardization YLLx, t, cr. Let’s calculate -cause YLL, Yll rate ASYR using Rosbris data downloaded. ASYR one needs standard population. Let’s use 2010 population standard (note, case ASYR equals YLL rate use 2010 mortality). Also one can calculate different YLL measures using standards provided demor dataframe.

what: Age and cause decomposition of differences in life expectancies
title: Basic functions for demographic analysis
text: Also one can decomposition 2 populations age causes. Lets use example Andreev & Shkolnikov spreadsheet data US England Wales men mortality causes presented. Lets see data mdecomp 2 lists arrays 2 population required. let us plot result mdecomp using ggplot2. requires data transformations
code: data("mdecompex") head(mdecompex) #> # A tibble: 6 × 9 #>     age neoplasms circulatory respiratory  digestive  accident     other     all #>   <dbl>     <dbl>       <dbl>       <dbl>      <dbl>     <dbl>     <dbl>   <dbl> #> 1     0 0.0000349  0.000173    0.000188   0.000151   0.000377  0.00669   7.62e-3 #> 2     1 0.0000309  0.0000155   0.0000220  0.00000930 0.000163  0.000112  3.53e-4 #> 3     5 0.0000313  0.00000560  0.00000687 0.00000324 0.0000792 0.0000409 1.67e-4 #> 4    10 0.0000305  0.0000127   0.00000896 0.00000286 0.000127  0.0000490 2.31e-4 #> 5    15 0.0000424  0.0000322   0.0000141  0.00000401 0.000765  0.0000821 9.40e-4 #> 6    20 0.0000600  0.0000511   0.0000158  0.00000928 0.00114   0.000130  1.41e-3 #> # ℹ 1 more variable: cnt <chr> #US men mx1 <- list(all = mdecompex[mdecompex$cnt=="usa",]$all,              neoplasm = mdecompex[mdecompex$cnt=="usa",]$neoplasms,              circulatory = mdecompex[mdecompex$cnt=="usa",]$circulatory,              respiratory = mdecompex[mdecompex$cnt=="usa",]$respiratory,             digestive = mdecompex[mdecompex$cnt=="usa",]$digestive,             accident = mdecompex[mdecompex$cnt=="usa",]$accident,             other = mdecompex[mdecompex$cnt=="usa",]$other) #England and Wales men mx2 <- list(all = mdecompex[mdecompex$cnt=="eng",]$all,              neoplasm = mdecompex[mdecompex$cnt=="eng",]$neoplasms,              circulatory = mdecompex[mdecompex$cnt=="eng",]$circulatory,              respiratory = mdecompex[mdecompex$cnt=="eng",]$respiratory,             digestive = mdecompex[mdecompex$cnt=="eng",]$digestive,             accident = mdecompex[mdecompex$cnt=="eng",]$accident,             other = mdecompex[mdecompex$cnt=="eng",]$other)  decm <- mdecomp(mx1 = mx1,                mx2 = mx2,                sex = "m",                age = unique(mdecompex$age)               ) head(decm) #>   age ex12      neoplasm  circulatory   respiratory     digestive   accident #> 1   0 0.12  0.0008745885 6.544742e-03  0.0038965543  6.616401e-03 0.02107294 #> 2   1 0.03 -0.0025030458 5.483996e-04  0.0020247182  6.245908e-04 0.03637029 #> 3   5 0.02 -0.0016468368 8.262058e-05 -0.0001300012  9.929857e-05 0.02178479 #> 4  10 0.01 -0.0014084238 4.993427e-04 -0.0002451017  8.338450e-05 0.01117647 #> 5  15 0.13 -0.0032690840 2.657675e-03  0.0005053688 -2.052103e-04 0.13796276 #> 6  20 0.17 -0.0009648903 2.773336e-03 -0.0016773417 -8.983808e-04 0.18353643 #>           other #> 1  0.0809947781 #> 2 -0.0070649563 #> 3 -0.0001898743 #> 4 -0.0001056675 #> 5 -0.0076515085 #> 6 -0.0127691565 library(ggplot2)  decm_plot <- decm[,c(1,3)] decm_plot$group = colnames(decm)[3] colnames(decm_plot)[2]<-"ex12" for(i in 4:ncol(decm)){   decm_plot_i <- decm[,c(1,i)]   decm_plot_i$group = colnames(decm)[i]   colnames(decm_plot_i)[2]<-"ex12"   decm_plot <- rbind(decm_plot,decm_plot_i)   rm(decm_plot_i) }  for (i in unique(decm_plot$group)){   decm_plot[decm_plot$group==i,]$group <- paste0(i, " (", round(sum(decm_plot[decm_plot$group==i,]$ex12),2), ")") }  ggplot(data = decm_plot, aes(x = as.factor(age), y = ex12, fill = group))+   geom_bar(stat="identity", colour = "black")+   theme_minimal()+   scale_fill_brewer(palette="Set1")+   labs(x = "Age", y = "Contribution to difference in ex", fill = "Cause (contribution):",         caption  = paste0("Total difference in ex = ", sum(decm[,2]))        )

title: Basic functions for demographic analysis
text: Also demor leecart() function provides users basic Lee-Carter model (proposed Lee Carter 1992 now lot extensions) mortality forecasting: One can plot results using ggplot2 comapare predicted data actual , however, requires data handling:
code: leecart_forecast <- leecart(data = dbm[dbm$code==1100 & dbm$territory=="t" & dbm$sex=="m" & dbm$year %in% 2004:2019,c("year", "age", "mx")],                              n = 5,                              sex = "m",                              concise = T                             ) head(leecart_forecast) #>   year age           mx     mx_low95    mx_high95    ex ex_low95 ex_high95 #> 1 2020   0 0.0052050868 0.0049297552 0.0054957958 68.54    67.99     69.08 #> 2 2020   1 0.0003032973 0.0002852915 0.0003224396 67.89    67.36     68.42 #> 3 2020  10 0.0002669130 0.0002568045 0.0002774194 63.97    63.45     64.50 #> 4 2020  15 0.0007304609 0.0006953816 0.0007673099 59.06    58.53     59.58 #> 5 2020  20 0.0013011257 0.0012188971 0.0013889016 54.26    53.75     54.78 #> 6 2020  25 0.0019688556 0.0018300568 0.0021181815 49.60    49.10     50.10 #LE data calculation ledata <- data.frame(year = 2010:2022, lem = NA, lem.predicted = NA, ci.low = NA, ci.high = NA) for(i in 2010:2022){   ledata[ledata$year==i,2] <- LT(age = unique(dbm$age),                                   sex = "m",                                   mx = dbm[dbm$year==i &                                              dbm$territory == "t" &                                              dbm$code == 1100 &                                              dbm$sex == "m",]$mx)[1,"ex"]   if(i>=2019){     if(i==2019){       ledata[ledata$year==i,3:5] <- rep(ledata[ledata$year==i,2],3)     }else{       ledata[ledata$year==i,3:5] <- leecart_forecast[leecart_forecast$age=="0" &                                                       leecart_forecast$year == i,6:8] %>% as.numeric()     }   } }  ggplot(data = ledata, aes(x = year))+   geom_point(aes(y = lem, color = "Observed data"))+   geom_line(aes(y = lem, color = "Observed data"))+   geom_point(aes(y = lem.predicted, color = "Predicted data"))+   geom_line(aes(y = lem.predicted, color = "Predicted data"))+   geom_ribbon(aes(ymin = ci.low, ymax = ci.high), fill = "pink", alpha = 0.5)+   geom_vline(xintercept = 2019, linetype = "dashed", color = "darkgrey", size = 1)+   scale_x_continuous(breaks = 2010:2022)+   scale_y_continuous(breaks = 63:70)+   theme_minimal()+   theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 45, vjust = 1, hjust=1))+   scale_color_manual(values = c("black", "darkred"))+   labs(x="Year", y = "Male's LE at birth", colour = "") ggplot(data = leecart_forecast, aes(as.numeric(age), log10(mx), color = as.factor(year)))+   geom_line()+geom_ribbon(aes(ymin = log10(mx_low95), ymax = log10(mx_high95)), alpha = 0)+   theme_minimal()+   labs(x = "Age", color = "Year:")

title: Basic functions for demographic analysis
text: asdt() function calculates associated single decrement life table (ASDT) causes death (cause-deleted life table). words, function one can answer question “life expectancy mortality cause ?” example demor data (easy guess, taken Andreev & Shkolnikov spreadsheet) mortality US men 2002 causes added. Let show ex deaths neoplasm () One can plot results using ggplot2:
code: data("asdtex")  asdt_neoplasm <- asdt(age = asdtex$age,                        sex = "m",                       m_all = asdtex$all,                        m_i = asdtex$neoplasms,                        full = F,                        method = "chiang1968") asdt_neoplasm[,c("age", "ex", "ex_without_i")] #>    age    ex ex_without_i #> 1    0 74.65        78.58 #> 2    1 74.22        78.18 #> 3    5 70.32        74.28 #> 4   10 65.38        69.33 #> 5   15 60.45        64.39 #> 6   20 55.72        59.67 #> 7   25 51.10        55.06 #> 8   30 46.43        50.39 #> 9   35 41.75        45.72 #> 10  40 37.16        41.13 #> 11  45 32.70        36.64 #> 12  50 28.39        32.26 #> 13  55 24.25        27.98 #> 14  60 20.32        23.82 #> 15  65 16.69        19.84 #> 16  70 13.40        16.12 #> 17  75 10.51        12.75 #> 18  80  8.07         9.81 #> 19  85  6.15         7.32 library(ggplot2)  ggplot(data = asdt_neoplasm, aes(x = age))+   geom_line(aes(y = ex, color = "ex"), size = 1)+   geom_line(aes(y = ex_without_i, color = "ex without neoplasms"), size = 1)+   theme_minimal() ggplot(data = asdt_neoplasm, aes(x = age))+   geom_line(aes(y = lx, color = "ex"), size = 1)+   geom_line(aes(y = l_not_i, color = "ex without neoplasms"), size = 1)+   geom_hline(yintercept = 0.5, linetype = "dashed")+   theme_classic()

title: Basic functions for demographic analysis
text: analysis fertility demor (1…) functions, due author’s preference mortality analysis…

title: Basic functions for demographic analysis
text: Lets get basic fertility data (asFR fx) RosBris using get_rosbris() example Russia-2010 gotten Now one can compute TFR:
code: dbf <- get_rosbris(   #fertility data   type = "f",   #what age group download   age =  5,   #to get "long" data   initial = F,   #last available year   lastyear = 2022 ) rus2010f <- dbf[dbf$year==2010 & dbf$code==1100 & dbf$territory=="t",] rus2010f #>      year code territory age       fx       N        Bx                 name #> 3153 2010 1100         t  15 0.027015 4214250 113847.96 Российская Федерация #> 3154 2010 1100         t  20 0.087421 6027079 526893.27 Российская Федерация #> 3155 2010 1100         t  25 0.099061 5957982 590203.65 Российская Федерация #> 3156 2010 1100         t  30 0.067240 5515957 370892.95 Российская Федерация #> 3157 2010 1100         t  35 0.029922 5187670 155225.46 Российская Федерация #> 3158 2010 1100         t  40 0.005904 4764028  28126.82 Российская Федерация #> 3159 2010 1100         t  45 0.000257 5738736   1474.86 Российская Федерация #> 3160 2010 1100         t  50 0.000014 6203597     86.85 Российская Федерация tfr(   #asFR   rus2010f$fx,   #age interval   age.int = 5     ) #> [1] 1.58417

title: Basic functions for demographic analysis
text: Also demor additional functions. One plot_pyr plots population pyramid using ggplot2 Lets create population pyramid using midyear population Rosbris mortality data. already data dbm.  Also one can redesigned plot using ggplot2 functions:
code: plot_pyr(   popm = dbm[dbm$year==2010 & dbm$code==1100 & dbm$territory=="t" & dbm$sex=="m",]$N,   popf = dbm[dbm$year==2010 & dbm$code==1100 & dbm$territory=="t" & dbm$sex=="f",]$N,    ages = dbm[dbm$year==2010 & dbm$code==1100 & dbm$territory=="t" & dbm$sex=="f",]$age) plot <-    plot_pyr(   popm = dbm[dbm$year==2010 & dbm$code==1100 & dbm$territory=="t" & dbm$sex=="m",]$N,   popf = dbm[dbm$year==2010 & dbm$code==1100 & dbm$territory=="t" & dbm$sex=="f",]$N,    ages = dbm[dbm$year==2010 & dbm$code==1100 & dbm$territory=="t" & dbm$sex=="f",]$age)  plot +    labs(y = "My y", x = "Age")+   theme_minimal()

title: Basic functions for demographic analysis

Average age death infancy infant mortality level: Reconsidering Coale-Demeny formulas current levels low mortality. Demographic Research, 33, 363-390. Ghislandi, S., Sanderson, W. C., & Scherbov, S. (2019). simple measure human development: human life indicator. Population development review, 45(1), 219-233. Andreev, E. M., & Shkolnikov, V. M. (2012). Excel spreadsheet decomposition difference two values aggregate demographic measure stepwise replacement running young old ages. MPIDR Technical Report TR-2012-002. URL Lee, R. D., & Carter, L. R. (1992). Modeling forecasting US mortality. Journal American statistical association, 87(419), 659-671. Ghislandi, S., Sanderson, W.C., & Scherbov, S. (2019). Simple Measure Human Development: Human Life Indicator. Population Development Review, 45, 219–233.

text: age Array age intervals; full life table = 0:100; concise life table = c(0:1, seq(5,85,5)) sex Sex. "m" males "f" females. m_all Age specific mortality rates causes death m_i Age specific mortality rates cause death () full Logical. full table needed? TRUE = full, FALSE = concise method method ASDT construction use. Now just "chiang1968" supported.

T initial, F 'long' format (default). lastyear Numeric. last available year rosbris (can seen website). Default 2022 (2023).

title: Years of Life Lost (YLL) calculation — yll
text: Dx Array number deaths. type Character. Type YLL calculate. See details section. Dx_all Array number deaths. Used yll.p type, Dx array cause-specific deaths. pop Array population. Used yll.r asyr types. w Array population weights direct standardization. Used asyr type.

title: Years of Life Lost (YLL) calculation — yll
text: list values.

title: Years of Life Lost (YLL) calculation — yll
text: Possible YLL types: Absolute number YLL - yll type. YLL proportion - yll.p type. YLL rate - yll.r type. Age-standardized YLL rate  - asyr type. details see github page.
